4D52D7AC61EB4C53A8E8315CB3889BE4.description: select and use productivity tools found in spread sheet, word processing, and publication applications to create digital artifacts, including reports, graphs, and charts, with increasing complexity.

7B0597B4837247709D0A53503573DEEE.description: compare types of local and remote data storage such as cloud architecture or local server and select the appropriate type of storage to store and share data; and

BB5A1483CCE943B1816633D1CA993BE7.description: apply appropriate troubleshooting techniques and seek technical assistance as needed;

C1EF9A6F7A8E4CE2A82886409F8B3CEF.description: select and use appropriate shortcuts within applications;

78C64FBAF455414DA26BEA489DBDEFA9.description: demonstrate improvement in speed and accuracy as measured by words per minute when applying correct keyboarding techniques;

538D7AC37071464AA73C84173B18A30A.description: select and use appropriate platform and tools, including selecting and using software or hardware to transfer data;

FE7000502F824ADB867C2DADCA7A5804.description: implement effective file management strategies independently, including file naming conventions, local and remote locations, backup, hierarchy, folder structure, file conversion, tags, and emerging digital organizational strategies;

A3EF4AB8E2284B51B2A1F5069298FAED.description: integrate use of appropriate technology terminology in scholarly inquiry and dialogue such as classroom discussion and written samples;

B08DDD9791A64B868A9C5A921691A5D4.description: Practical technology concepts--skills and tools. The student leverages technology systems, concepts, and operations to produce digital artifacts. The student is expected to:

6CAC06FF3F174473AE5BD0A7A0B5435A.description: share and seek feedback on files in various formats, including text, raster and vector graphics, video, and audio files.

21DE4BB676F54C3CAE527BB267C66C9A.description: combine various file formats for a specific project or audience; and

72D365AA00864793A34BE47E6E5FBAAB.description: Practical technology concepts--processes. The student evaluates and selects appropriate methods or techniques for an independent project and identifies and solves common hardware and software problems using troubleshooting strategies. The student is expected to:

B813B2C1D9A6494D95C10AA354B20B33.description: evaluate scenarios or case studies to identify warning signs of a cyberbullying victim such as withdrawal or lack of sleep and predict the outcomes for both the victim and the bully.

B19529A06A7449DDA67FAB0C3B1343C8.description: analyze real-world scenarios to identify cybersecurity threats and propose ways to prevent harm; and

377A1DD142144F6BB36A24F41830EBD7.description: Digital citizenship--privacy, safety, and security. The student practices safe, legal, and ethical digital behaviors to become a socially responsible digital citizen. The student is expected to:

78FA105A6E22488C8AF56F364A5DC9DC.description: evaluate the bias of digital information sources, including websites.

4C75C9118C244898A3FEDE7CE5E08E50.description: create citations and cite sources for a variety of digital forms of intellectual property; and

8F928E147B354AA18DCF1BF2109DEBE1.description: adhere to appropriate intellectual property law when creating digital products;

26FD706F9B1341A69217B54470DE1AA1.description: adhere to local acceptable use policy (AUP) and practice and advocate for safe, ethical, and positive online behaviors;

B0998C1C6FC849128B201F98A0E76BD5.description: Digital citizenship--ethics and laws. The student recognizes and practices responsible, legal, and ethical behavior while using digital tools and resources. The student is expected to:

1E56E9F2BE774061A8BA2079F3DD4F86.description: collaborate and publish for a global audience on digital platforms such as recording and editing videos using appropriate formal and informal digital etiquette.

389339D78CDE465FADA818899CC381D8.description: create and publish a formal digital communication for a global audience using appropriate digital etiquette; and

EB5484427F184EBE81ECBD2DB175187C.description: analyze the importance of managing a digital footprint and how a digital footprint can affect the future;

E9545AD5DA954A76A3980A8E1AEDD3C4.description: Digital citizenship--social interactions. The student understands different styles of digital communication and that a student's actions online can have a long-term impact. The student is expected to:

23945C5809A8403BBCB57E4D7EC7C09D.description: Data literacy, management, and representation--communicate and publish results. The student creates digital products to communicate data to an audience for an intended purpose. The student is expected to use digital tools to communicate and publish data from a product or process to persuade an intended audience.

75A478A81C5E439BBBD500B6BF877681.description: Data literacy, management, and representation--organize, manage, and analyze data. The student uses digital tools to transform data, make inferences, and predictions. The student is expected to use digital tools in order to transform data, analyze trends, and predict possibilities and develop steps for the creation of an innovative process or product.

55BCB3CF5E584D828CDDAE0A2D487AC4.description: apply appropriate search strategies, including keywords, Boolean operators, and limiters, to achieve a specified outcome that includes a variety of file formats.

2CF3E672706648EDAED99F139E3FD143.description: compare and contrast data types, including binary, integers, real numbers, Boolean data, and text-based representations; and

9613CE7B655149B4B554572D19904A0B.description: Data literacy, management, and representation--collect data. The student uses advanced digital strategies to collect and represent data. The student is expected to:

8B10F89CC129438DB33F4D491274A92D.description: transfer current knowledge to the learning of newly encountered technologies.

FB4D9CB0EC4E4EB295B88C0A862F5CED.description: evaluate and predict how global trends impact the development of technology; and

89FBB380BEC04E27BDFBD0C31AB1140C.description: evaluate how changes in technology throughout history have impacted various areas of study;

F0AC25054A4444268D4B66589BDFFE4A.description: Creativity and innovation--emerging technologies. The student demonstrates a thorough understanding of the role of technology throughout history and its impact on societies. The student is expected to:

E2E168B7BF704FB6A2A584227B65DFD5.description: identify how the design process is used in various industries.

50E4279FD9074A4693A06FEC68B76A46.description: discuss and implement a design process that includes planning, selecting digital tools to develop, test, and evaluate design limitations, and refining a prototype or model; and

FA4B21CB45CF49EFA99DFE4E28E4A00B.description: demonstrate innovation in a design process using goal setting and personal character traits, including demonstrating calculated risk-taking and tolerance;

460DFF700F01422ABC2C48141550A824.description: Creativity and innovation--innovative design process. The student takes an active role in learning by using a design process and creative thinking to develop and evaluate solutions, considering a variety of local and global perspectives. The student is expected to:

9D9E8E1E060141D3A66C215346A2561B.description: modify and implement previously written code to develop improved programs.

E2A81DCD26984B0FB6D7219BC7E0F804.description: use a software design process to create text-based programs with nested loops that address different subproblems within a real-world context; and

77180A03EA2E40CDBEF6B8F244AC8C6E.description: construct named variables with multiple data types and perform operations on their values;

D8A219F25F6140FAB5F0E3987293564F.description: Computational thinking--applications. The student applies the fundamentals of computer science. The student is expected to:

B4C10E8B01E54B45A75A28782583C3A0.description: analyze the benefits of using iteration (code and sequence repetition) in algorithms.

7C587E8643604AEA896EF6640B2E5F32.description: develop, compare, and improve algorithms for a specific task to solve a problem; and

36C841DAEC0D4A7B9716C4AC35B3D527.description: design a plan collaboratively using pseudocode to document a problem, possible solutions, and an expected timeline for the development of a coded solution;

7F6E5EB0A3C84E09AC7AEB55177C510D.description: practice abstraction by developing a generalized algorithm that can solve different types of problems;

63E15908844749A5ABD5C5D96CCBE675.description: analyze the patterns and sequences found in pseudocode and identify its variables;

4E1FF30A2F1F4335A3625AFBA94AAA74.description: decompose real-world problems into structured parts using pseudocode;

C65A0B1AF9D24B6C80B772FE1C3429F2.description: Computational thinking--foundations. The student explores the core concepts of computational thinking, a set of problem-solving processes that involve decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithms. The student is expected to:Â

4BDF88E8F3BF434F86191EEFC8C17068.description: Statements containing the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

A04ECEAEA19E4FDB8C08E92996E495F2.description: The technology applications TEKS can be integrated into all content areas and can support stand-alone courses. Districts have the flexibility of offering technology applications in a variety of settings, including through a stand-alone course or by integrating the technology applications standards in the essential knowledge and skills for one or more courses or subject areas.

AE33A75A1A4C48DCAECA830EB1B94266.description: Practical technology concepts. Students build their knowledge of software applications and hardware focusing on keyboarding and use of applications and tools. Students also build their knowledge and use of technology systems, including integrating the use of multiple applications.

9DE5DC9E329147BC81114EF73005DCA0.description: Digital citizenship. Students practice the ethical and effective application of technology and develop an understanding of cybersecurity and the impact of a digital footprint to become safe, productive, and respectful digital citizens.

6292E86EF7D648F49A9AF022BC682821.description: Data literacy, management, and representation. Students collect, organize, manage, analyze, and publish various types of data for an audience.

82C194881DF94A199DE21A434587EB7B.description: Creativity and innovation. Students use innovative design processes to develop solutions to problems. Students plan a solution, create the solution, test the solution, iterate, and debug the solution as needed, and implement a completely new and innovative product.

91D35E44E0044371B79BE1CB9E1FDA1A.description: Computational thinking. Students break down the problem-solving process into four steps: decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithms.

0FA26F032E9947C08069CE564EFA05B5.description: The technology applications Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) consist of five strands that prepare students to be literate in technology applications by Grade 8: computational thinking; creativity and innovation; data literacy, management, and representation; digital citizenship; and practical technology concepts. Communication and collaboration skills are embedded across the strands.

27A575C9C2B843F08896F7DFA4552FCE.description: Technology includes data communication, data processing, and the devices used for these tasks locally and across networks. Learning to apply these technologies motivates students to develop critical-thinking skills, higher-order thinking, and innovative problem solving. Technology applications incorporates the study of digital tools, devices, communication, and programming to empower students to apply current and emerging technologies in their careers, their education, and beyond.

9DA4A7484998427AB88E5AD4F68E9882.description: If the commissioner does not make the determination that instructional materials funding has been made available under this subsection, the commissioner shall determine no later than August 1 of each subsequent school year whether instructional materials funding has been made available. If the commissioner determines that instructional materials funding has been made available, the commissioner shall notify the State Board of Education and school districts that this section shall be implemented for the following school year.

93144A654C3042CBBC17832330EF1BFF.description: If the commissioner makes the determination that instructional materials funding has been made available this section shall be implemented beginning with the 2024-2025 school year and apply to the 2024-2025 and subsequent school years.

0D43C05C281546489D61CBA5DFC4048B.description: No later than August 1, 2024, the commissioner of education shall determine whether instructional materials funding has been made available to Texas public schools for materials that cover the essential knowledge and skills identified in this section.

4837A5AE27FA4170A68240D3BF25F9B6.description: Implementation. The provisions of this section shall be implemented by school districts beginning with the 2024-2025 school year.
